Situation1: They join in when the family talks about possible weekend plans.
Situation2: A dispatch call sends the ambulance driver through heavy city traffic to a location where a patient has a non-life-threatening injury.
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, half-listening as my stepbrother excitedly listed ideas for our weekend together—hiking, a movie, maybe even a family barbecue. My stepmom smiled at me, expecting me to chime in, to show I was part of this family now. I wanted to be present, to laugh and plan with them, but my phone buzzed, and I glanced down to see the ambulance dispatch alert flash across the screen. A call had come in: a patient with a minor injury, but the address was across town, and traffic was already thick. I was expected to get there quickly, but above all, to drive safely—no shortcuts, no risks. My stepbrother looked at me, waiting for my answer about the weekend, while my mind raced with the responsibility of the patient waiting for help. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, the family’s hope for connection and the city’s expectation for calm, careful urgency. My heart pounded as I stood, torn between the warmth of belonging and the duty of care, knowing I couldn’t give both what they needed from me in this moment.
